h1.a: Circus Factions in the Eastern Empire

div.p: A corpus of the epigraphic evidence

A collection of currently known inscribed references to the Circus Factions in the eastern empire, beyond Constantinople, was first made in 1966 by Α. Christophilopoulou; Alan Cameron then developed this in an Appendix to his 1976 study, Circus Factions. An expanded list was presented in 2021 by Roueché for a publication in memory of Alan Cameron (for all these see further Bibliography/Concordance). These publications were simple assemblies or lists of texts, without the opportunity to present them in context. The aim of this article is to explore the benefits of online publication for a presentation of this kind. The material can, of course, be presented in full, with detailed descriptions of each of the 80 texts identified. In most cases it allows for illustration of those texts. Perhaps more importantly, it supports the categorisation of the items in various ways, which may help us to greater understanding of their function and significance.

Cameron presented the items by geographical area: but this form of presentation - imposed by a list in analogue form - perhaps obscures other differentiating features. For the geographic distribution see Index of Findspots. To some extent the distribution reflects the intensity of study in certain areas: there is for example a great deal of material from the well-excavated sites of Aphrodisias and Ephesus, and 80 texts come from only 30 locations. Of those, only 7 had hippodromes; but this simply demonstrated, as Cameron showed, that interest in the factions spread far beyond the hippodrome.

Out of 80 texts the majority (50) have been recorded in situ, from sites which were not overlaid by further development after the seventh century.
The locations can therefore be examined: see Search, under Monument Type. Many of the locations (27) are in auditoria, as might be expected, or in streets, stairways and colonnades (16), where they may reflect the involvement of the factions in public ceremonial activities. But some are found in a domestic context - and four are associated with churches.

The texts can be analysed by type: see Search, under Text Type. Three people are identified by their factional loyalties in their epitaphs; there are also 11 place inscriptions. But three-quarters - 60 - are acclamations, 49 of which are calls for victory, Νικᾷ ἡ τύχη. Of these 6 also include the fortune of the emperor(s), (7, 8, 9, 11, 14, 15), and two the fortune of the city (35, 55). Those seem clearly to have a public - ?official - function; Some acclamations, however, are clearly private - for example on a comb (75), or a pithos (61).

The function of a text sometimes indicated by its support (see Search, under Support Object Type). 10 acclamations are on seating - which might mark official or unofficial allocation; 6 other seats have place inscriptions. Several place inscriptions() are on columns; this is not unusual for place inscriptions, although it is sometimes unclear exactly what space they are defining. Their meaning may of course vary, and I have argued that it some cases an acclamation, or a place inscription, may indicate the location of a group at the time of a public event (Roueché (1999)). The texts on a column at Oxyrhynchus (76XX) now unfortunately lost, may indicate this: the "place of the Blues" may indicate where they stood on such an occasion, and the acclamation for Phocas may be what they then performed. It wold be dangerous to interpret this, as some have done, as evidence of a special relationship: it is entirely possible that there was a place of the Greens on another column, with a similar acclamation. To be acclaimed by both factions was a far greater expression of power and stability than to be aligned with only one; I have suggested a similar arrangement on the "Gate of Hadrian" at Ephesus, Roueché (1999), no.7.

Execution? Traditional scholarship for many years saw such texts as insignificant; they were often classified as miscellaneous, or with the rather unclear designation of graffiti, applied both to content and to form. We have a better understanding now of the role of acclamations, and the study of late antique epigraphy has helped us appreciate styles of inscription that may have seemed inferior or casual. Some texts are clearly the work of a mason with a chisel, even if the alignment is inelegant. The manner of inscribing is clearly important: see Search, under Execution. But whether an inscription can be understood as public/official or private/unofficial remains difficult in many cases. But this is not definitive. It may be that we need further descriptive categories for defining various forms of non-standard execution; but the interpretation of some texts and their function remains difficult.
